content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun, just about achievable in low level language in time. A fair number of checks but no more than other pattern matching clashes.
Like it, managed to solve it in C detecting the '*' mines and incrementing an empty grid with checks at end in case a mine is incremented.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to understand and thought-provoking puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea. Although I solved the puzzle in 8 minutes (in a lazy mode before going to sleep), I think the puzzle is not difficult and can be solved in 5 minutes.
updated, removed spaces from columns and changed empty squares to '-'

I think using spaces is confusing and will cause an unnecessary hurdle for parsing the input since you also use spaces as column separators. You could use underscores instead?
_ _ _ * _
_ * _ * _
_ _ _ _ _
_ * _ _ _ ?

Pretty tough challenge, but I think I solved it in around 15-20 minutes. You're meant to be able to solve in 5 minutes to approve, so I can't approve it.

I also agree that it would be good to have a simpler 1st case to warm people up e.g:
_ _ _
_ * _
_ _ _

It would be helpful to add simpler test cases. The problems you provide only differ in scale, but it's the computer that handles the scale aspect, so they are all basically the same. Providing simpler test cases will make it easier to debug.  For example, 2x2 and 3x3 cases
If you downvote please take the time to say why so that I can improve the submission

* "Next n Lines: Each row of the board, space separated"
This needs rephrasing, as rows of the board are not space separated - but chars in the row are - which then doesn't fit the "square" definition from the @Goal (the example is 5x9 instead of 5x5).

* "First Number: Size of board n"
If you really mean a square, then what you are supplying here (n) is the size of an "edge of a square" - as the size of a "square board" is "n*n".
If you take my first point above into account, then what you are supplying here is the size of an "edge of a rectangle", while the top/bottom sizes differ from it, except in 1x1 board's case.

A test case & validator, for both variations of the 1x1 boards, look like a must here.

Thanks! Definitely added those tests. Wording should be a bit better, lmk. Even though it looks better, I could just get rid of the spaced completely because in a quick clash could definitely be a bit confusing
Put in the 5x5 for that purpose, but adding in more tests doesnt really hurt anything
I can solve in 3-5 minuted using python, c++ and Java, so I thought it was fine. Getting surrounding indexes is a pretty well used/known algorithm with a bunch of ways to do it.

ie 2**21
    *54*2
    *3*3*
    23332
    1*2*1
and same for the unput
